controls.title: Ensure atm kernel module is not available
controls.description:
\

\f2\b0 The Asynchronous Transfer Mode (ATM) is a protocol operating on network, data link,\
and physical layers, based on virtual circuits and virtual paths. Disabling ATM protects\
the system against exploitation of any laws in its implementation.\

\f1\b
controls.rationale:
\

\f2\b0 Removing support for unneeded protocols reduces the local attack surface of the\
system. If this protocol is not needed, disable it.
\fs20\fsmilli10080 Page 417\

\f0 Internal Only - General\

\f1\b\fs24
controls.audit_command:
\

\f2\b0 Verify the 
\f0 \cf4 atm
\f2 \cf2  kernel module is not available on the system or has been disabled.\
1. Run the following script to determine if the 
\f0 \cf4 atm
\f2 \cf2  kernel module is available on the\
system:\

\f4\fs20\fsmilli10080 #!/usr/bin/env bash\
\{\
l_mod_name="atm" l_mod_type="net"\
while IFS= read -r l_mod_path; do\
if [ -d "$l_mod_path/$\{l_mod_name//-/\\/\}" ] && \\\
[ -n "$(ls -A "$l_mod_path/$\{l_mod_name//-/\\/\}")" ]; then\
printf '%s\\n' "$l_mod_name exists in
controls.remediation:
\

\f2\b0 Unload and disable the 
\f0 \cf4 atm
\f2 \cf2  kernel module.\
1. Run the following commands to unload the 
\f0 \cf4 atm
\f2 \cf2  kernel module:\

\f4\fs20\fsmilli10080 # modprobe -r atm 2>/dev/null\
# rmmod can 2>/dev/null\

\f2\fs24 2. Perform the following to disable the 
\f0 \cf4 atm
\f2 \cf2  kernel module:\
Create a file ending in 
\f0 \cf4 .conf
\f2 \cf2  with 
\f0 \cf4 install can /bin/false
\f2 \cf2  in the 
\f0 \cf4 /etc/modprobe.d/\

\f2 \cf2 directory\

\f3\i Example:\

\f4\i0\fs20\fsmilli10080 # printf '\\n%s\\n' "install atm /bin/false" >> /etc/modprobe.d/60-atm.conf\

\f2\fs24 Create a file ending in 
\f0 \cf4 .conf
\f2 \cf2  with 
\f0 \cf4 blacklist atm
\f2 \cf2  in the 
\f0 \cf4 /etc/modprobe.d/
\f2 \cf2  directory\

\f3\i Example:\

\f4\i0\fs20\fsmilli10080 # p
controls.references:
\

\f2\b0 1. CCI-000381\
2. NIST SP 800-53 :: CM-7\
3. NIST SP 800-53A :: CM-7.1 (ii)\
4. STIG ID: RHEL-08-040021 | RULE ID: SV-230494r1069310 | CAT III\
5. STIG ID: OL08-00-040021 | RULE ID: SV-248829r991589 | CAT II\
6. STIG ID: RHEL-09-213045 | RULE ID: SV-257804r1044853 | CAT II\
7. STIG ID: ALM

controls.title: Ensure can kernel module is not available
controls.description:
\

\f2\b0 The Controller Area Network (CAN) is a serial communications protocol, which was\
initially developed for automotive and is now also used in marine, industrial, and\
medical applications. Disabling CAN protects the system against exploitation of any\
flaws in its implementation.\

\f1\b
controls.rationale:
\

\f2\b0 Removing support for unneeded protocols reduces the local attack surface of the\
system. If this protocol is not needed, disable it.
\fs20\fsmilli10080 Page 421\

\f0 Internal Only - General\

\f1\b\fs24
controls.audit_command:
\

\f0 \cf4 can

while IFS= read -r l_mod_path; do\
if [ -d "$l_mod_path/$\{l_mod_name//-/\\/\}" ] && \\\
[ -n "$(ls -A "$l_mod_path/$\{l_mod_name//-/\\/\}")" ]; then\
printf '%s\\n' "$l_mod_name exists in
controls.remediation:
\

\f0 \cf4 can
\f2 \cf2  kernel module.\
1. Run the following commands to unload the

\f2 \cf2  kernel module:\

# rmmod can 2>/dev/null\

\f2\fs24 2. Perform the following to disable the 
\f0 \cf4 can
\f2 \cf2  kernel module:\
Create a file ending in 
\f0 \cf4 .conf
\f2 \cf2  with 
\f0 \cf4 install can /bin/false
\f2 \cf2  in the 
\f0 \cf4 /etc/modprobe.d/\

\f2 \cf2 directory\

\f3\i Example:\

\f4\i0\fs20\fsmilli10080 # printf '\\n%s\\n' "install can /bin/false" >> /etc/modprobe.d/60-can.conf\

\f0 \cf4 .conf
\f2 \cf2  with 
\f0 \cf4 blacklist can
\f2 \cf2  in the 
\f0 \cf4 /etc/modprobe.d/

controls.title: Ensure dccp kernel module is not available
controls.description:
\

\f2\b0 The Datagram Congestion Control Protocol (DCCP) is a transport layer protocol that\
supports streaming media and telephony. DCCP provides a way to gain access to\
congestion control, without having to do it at the application layer, but does not provide\
in-sequence delivery.\

\f1\b
controls.rationale:
\

\f2\b0 Removing support for unneeded protocols reduces the local attack surface of the\
system. If this protocol is not needed, disable it.
\fs20\fsmilli10080 Page 425\

\f0 Internal Only - General\

\f1\b\fs24
controls.audit_command:
\

\f2\b0 Verify the 
\f0 \cf4 dccp
\f2 \cf2  kernel module is not available on the system or has been disabled.\
1. Run the following script to determine if the 
\f0 \cf4 dccp
\f2 \cf2  kernel module is available on the\
system:\

\f4\fs20\fsmilli10080 #!/usr/bin/env bash\
\{\
l_mod_name="dccp" l_mod_type="net"\
while IFS= read -r l_mod_path; do\
if [ -d "$l_mod_path/$\{l_mod_name//-/\\/\}" ] && \\\
[ -n "$(ls -A "$l_mod_path/$\{l_mod_name//-/\\/\}")" ]; then\
printf '%s\\n' "$l_mod_name exists
controls.remediation:
\

\f2\b0 Unload and disable the 
\f0 \cf4 dccp
\f2 \cf2  kernel module.\
1. Run the following commands to unload the 
\f0 \cf4 dccp
\f2 \cf2  kernel module:\

\f4\fs20\fsmilli10080 # modprobe -r dccp 2>/dev/null\
# rmmod dccp 2>/dev/null\

\f2\fs24 2. Perform the following to disable the 
\f0 \cf4 dccp
\f2 \cf2  kernel module:\
Create a file ending in 
\f0 \cf4 .conf
\f2 \cf2  with 
\f0 \cf4 install dccp /bin/false
\f2 \cf2  in the\

\f0 \cf4 /etc/modprobe.d/
\f2 \cf2  directory\

\f3\i Example:\

\f4\i0\fs20\fsmilli10080 # printf '\\n%s\\n' "install dccp /bin/false" >> /etc/modprobe.d/60-dccp.conf\

\f2\fs24 Create a file ending in 
\f0 \cf4 .conf
\f2 \cf2  with 
\f0 \cf4 blacklist dccp
\f2 \cf2  in the 
\f0 \cf4 /etc/modprobe.d/
\f2 \cf2  directory\

controls.title: Ensure rds kernel module is not available
controls.description:
\

\f2\b0 The Reliable Datagram Sockets (RDS) protocol is a transport layer protocol designed to\
provide low-latency, high-bandwidth communications between cluster nodes. It was\
developed by the Oracle Corporation.\

\f1\b
controls.rationale:
\

\f2\b0 Removing support for unneeded protocols reduces the local attack surface of the\
system. If this protocol is not needed, disable it.
\fs20\fsmilli10080 Page 428\

\f0 Internal Only - General\

\f1\b\fs24

controls.title: Ensure sctp kernel module is not available
controls.description:
\

\f2\b0 The Stream Control Transmission Protocol (SCTP) is a transport layer protocol used to\
support message oriented communication, with several streams of messages in one\
connection. It serves a similar function as TCP and UDP, incorporating features of both.\
It is message-oriented like UDP, and ensures reliable in-sequence transport of\
messages with congestion control like TCP.\

\f1\b
controls.rationale:
\

\f2\b0 Removing support for unneeded protocols reduces the local attack surface of the\
system. If this protocol is not needed, disable it.\

\f1\b
controls.audit_command:
\

\f0 \cf4 sctp

printf '%s\\n' "$l_mod_name exists

\f2 \cf2  kernel module:\

\f0 \cf4 .conf
\f2 \cf2  with 
\f0 \cf4 install sctp /bin/false
\f2 \cf2  in the\

\f0 \cf4 /etc/modprobe.d/
\f2 \cf2  directory\

\f0 \cf4 .conf
